3C15B54B92FB491DBA41001556AF9C7F.description: Identify the factors limiting population growth in a given area (carrying capacity).

64C8CA5795DF41B39F93B53FBF54A700.description:
Identify factors that influence patterns of ecological succession, including invasive
species, loss of biodiversity, change in abiotic conditions, and catastrophic events.

E41614882F154C0283A24D2C1E0C9E1D.description:
Recall the natural processes of change in the environment, including examples of
succession, evolution, and extinction.

F23A06D2AD924A5EA28FA9F60FA4D32B.description:
Differentiate that the Earth’s systems exist in a state of dynamic equilibrium and that
certain compositions of the Earth’s system(s) may fluctuate on short or long time
scales but the Earth’s system will generally stay within a certain narrow range for
millions of years.

CA96C3D72B674F499D3503F48B0AAA4B.description:
Identify the factors that have contributed to the growth of the human population and
examine the impact this growth will have on the environment.

A6F99A5ACF2C45F5AB5DB8A20F32B7CA.description:
Relate the importance of genetic diversity and population size to the conservation of a
species.

51A8CB35F71248E2B0756177F4B9C2F8.description:
Explain how organisms are adapted to the environment in terms of ecological niches
and natural selection.

81E28320BE854417A7FBE87D0BB8EE16.description: Assess the potential value of a single species to a particular ecosystem.

5A289DB813BF4156B80039FC49311ED1.description:
Describe the ways in which biodiversity is important to ecosystems and human
society.

A0D5CAE335604A13BB9786DF580D6214.description:
The student will analyze ecology as interrelationships, explain the transfer of
matter and energy within ecosystems, relate the theory of biological evolution to
geologic time and addresses speciation and biodiversity in the context of the
environment.

623E09D1AB0C4550ABDAABBEA8EDB5A5.description:
Generate predictive hypotheses predicting the effects of carbon dioxide on Earth’s
systems.

89C4BDFE65A946BE93CEA2FAA75515A4.description:
Organize evidence that Earth is a system containing essentially a fixed amount of each
stable chemical atom or element which moves among reservoirs in the solid Earth,
oceans, atmosphere, and organisms as part of geochemical cycles.

FCB783E74E8246F19610B24D9D4AD40D.description: Organize the multiple pathways of carbon movement between reservoirs.

2257F03FB0554508A5AE492D57233B32.description:
Generate examples of the Earth as a complex system with connected and
interconnected components and processes.

741FC0EEFE0D40DA9EE0FBEE2513B98B.description:
The student will explain how geochemical cycles and ecological processes on
Earth interact through time to cycle matter and energy and how human activity
can alter the rates of these processes.

C3B61533935943DE8030D2F50500DE44.description:
Summarize how changes in the availability of energy will affect society and human
activities, such as transportation, agricultural systems, and manufacturing.

EB979105BC2A47319203B85CBF595FF6.description:
Explain the ways in which individuals can alter their own behavior to reduce the human
carbon footprint.

248A2DF263734AE7AA670B82491C92B8.description: Hypothesize the use of renewable energies and the development of superior technologies impact upon the rate of depletion of natural resources.

7C10D693D3D04E2DA7B7CB952DA7B475.description:
Infer the effects of natural and human-caused activities that either contribute to or
challenge an ecologically sustainable environment.

76E51109726C4A6B9CDFE52A8C6CC21D.description:
Analyze the future availability of nonrenewable energy resources considering the trend
of human consumption of energy.

31E9AD13F76C4C56A3D670CE16DD17BA.description:
Interpret how changes to the availability of nonrenewable natural resources might
affect society (considering, for example, manufacturing industries, agriculture, and
transportation).

F3F9433D4589486A9CE23637E1D6B209.description:
Recognize that certain resources are nonrenewable because they are replenished at
timescales of thousands to millions of years.

04205A24F4934E1DA41BA03EA5BE50C2.description:
Illustrate the naturally occurring cycles of Earth’s finite resources through Earth’s four
major systems (atmosphere, hydrosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere) by describing the
path of an element or a molecule in a natural resource (for example carbon or water).

706C6EE1159543E5B06396E3DE8ECC8C.description: Explain how fossil fuels are formed and where they can be found.

E7C1FFDF20A2466E872F1B91E667D759.description:
The student will identify a variety of Earth’s finite natural resources, assess the
availability and sustainability of resources.

3777FCFB7E7E4E5ABC7964641AA4FEF5.description:
Assess the environmental and societal costs and benefits of various common natural
resource management strategies.

E1A1570BACCD4488B82EA0CCB7DF4A50.description:
Identify the effects of human activities on ecosystems at various scales in terms of
ecosystem functioning.

0A21FFFE38574C86A1CF6575DF573E2A.description:
Describe how people affect biodiversity through land use practices, pollution, and their
use of organisms.

923BEB3182EC416A93796ED1F8109BD4.description:
Evaluate a variety of land management practices on their ability to restore ecosystem
functioning and trophic relationships.

BEED786D57B74ACDA3EC580A5CD2FA35.description:
Recognize the ways in which technology, while improving our standard of living, has
increased the human impact on the environment.

339687E426EC4A0DB034F9D485B8D27E.description:
Provide evidence for how people impact their environment through the use of natural
resources.

4097CC4E746545A98FE4995C572C511C.description:
Describe the ways in which the use of technology has an affected the environment and
standard of living.

C4D28A25682E4313A96440344CD31D11.description:
Provide evidence for how human population growth has impacted the environment and
the use of natural resources.

AA6DE0784CA34ED0BC81D63964633552.description:
The student will identify the effect of human activities on natural processes and
interrelationships within ecosystems.

101EA010E12C4B8C8BE2A8544B89ADDC.description: Identify how the choices individuals make affect the environment.

465B54D50EC74F91B72A0AB9090392CB.description: Evaluating the ways in which government can influence environmental policy.

58F28EFD592A494998E741FB28D0E845.description:
Identify a variety of approaches to environmental issues and evaluates the benefits and
consequences of each from a social, economic, and ecological standpoint.

1029A60FC100474890D128C5359A9B01.description:
Explain how individual activities and decisions can have an impact on the
environment.

AABF6DD83C4C4764B373AE9ED97241EB.description:
Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of balancing short term interests with long
term welfare of the society.

4CD1EFCCFFEB4AC09DA2643DEB04B265.description:
Utilize research methods to investigate environmental questions, reevaluates their
personal beliefs to accommodate new knowledge and perspectives, and is able to
effectively communicate this understanding to others.

BB7F0654A4DD4A629E01EA4E6B09F43A.description:
The student will identify and describe current environmental issues, and
considers of the role of beliefs, attitudes, and values in proposing solutions to
environmental problems.

1D5B2309CA3649029CF24C97C113E5DB.description: Use appropriate safety procedures when conducting investigations.

CD338420E22B4C9FBEC11968344D4A46.description: Compare the processes of scientific investigation and technological design.

8E3451C3000A4CB39B6E10FD53B4E96B.description:
Evaluate a technological design or product on the basis of designated criteria
(including cost, time, and materials).

896051CFA7964997978FD35D845FE76E.description:
Evaluate the results of a controlled scientific investigation in terms of whether they
refute or verify the hypothesis.

BCE2E87181D04AE4B3CF6554380854BA.description:
Organize and interpret the data from a controlled scientific investigation by using
mathematics, graphs, models, and/or technology.

1B3CAB2322FD440E8CA16C8265206556.description:
Design a scientific investigation with appropriate methods of control to test a
hypothesis (including independent and dependent variables), and evaluate the designs
of sample investigations.

4F107E52AC3648E989763F94CE6C90A8.description:
Use scientific instruments to record measurement data in appropriate metric units that
reflect the precision and accuracy of each particular instrument.

F068A65F072A459FB6A825181C143AE8.description:
Use scientific instruments to record measurement data in appropriate metric units that
reflect the precision and accuracy of each particular instrument.

36D61355800D4C7AABC0A43BAA74B877.description:
Generate hypotheses based on credible, accurate, and relevant sources of scientific
information.

307DDBFE770F43E7A4E4B9C8008ECD94.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of how scientific inquiry and
technological design, including mathematical analysis, can be used appropriately
to pose questions, seek answers, and develop solutions.
